Thank you for tuning in all week as we shared our work in Peru! üáµüá™‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£To learn more about our work with Peru‚Äôs farmers and Indigenous forest communities, local governments, and smallholder farmer groups, visit rainforest-alliance.org ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£#RainforestAlliance #Peru #JoinOurAlliance #OurFamilyTree Photo: David Dudenhoefer

The new generation of Peruvian farmers, hyper-aware of the threats posed by our current #climatecrisis, is taking the lead in transforming their communities. Combining traditional ecological knowledge with climate-smart agriculture methods, they are cultivating a better future for themselves and their children. ‚Å£
‚Å£
The Rainforest Alliance is proud to be working with young people to cultivate thriving rural economies with forest conservation at their core. In doing so, they are carrying forward a centuries-old tradition of living in harmony with the Amazon.‚Å£
‚Å£
#RainforestAlliance #SaveTheForests #IndigenousRising #ActForAmazonia

üå± Cultivating sustainable forest economies is an important part of our commitment to supporting the ecological leadership of Indigenous people. And this commitment is core to our long-term vision of a rebalanced Earth. ‚Å£
‚Å£
In the San Mart√≠n region of Peru, on the outskirts of the Amazon, we work with eight Indigenous communities to bring their products to market while conserving the forest. One of them, the community of Yurilamas, in the province of Lamas, sets aside 26,000 ha (64,200 acres) of its lands for conservation and uses another 7,000 hectares to cultivate cocoa, as well as beans, bananas, yucca, peanuts, and more. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Our work has expanded to the Amazonas region of Peru, as well. Partnering with DAR Per√∫, we now work with Indigenous groups around the communal reserve of Chayu Nain. Together, we're providing fire prevention and business management training, as well as facilitating access to markets to support the development of the local Indigenous economy.‚Å£
‚Å£
Read more about our ongoing partnerships in Peru, and why they are absolutely critical to our mission, via the link in our bio. ‚Å£
‚Å£
#RainforestAlliance #ActForAmazonia #SaveTheForests #Peru #IndigenousRising

Did you know that Peru's fertile land produces such great amounts of coffee that the country is the number one exporter of organic coffee worldwide!? Yet while the climate crisis poses challenges to farmers of all crops, it especially threatens coffee.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Working with coffee and cocoa farmers to build resilience to climate impacts is a major focus of the Rainforest Alliance‚Äôs work in Peru. ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Creating a ground-breaking #climatesmartagriculture guide is one powerful solution we've applied for these landscapes in particular. Based on data collected over 13 years, the guide gives detailed instructions on how to deal with specific, climate-related problems to avoid crop loss.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£#RainforestAlliance #RainforestAllianceCertified #Peru #ClimateResilience #SustainableAgriculture #ClimateSmart #FollowTheFrog Photo: David Dudenhoefer

The megadiverse Peruvian Amazon teems with wildlife and plant species. Indigenous communities have lived in harmony with nature for centuries by applying their traditional ecological expertise. Coffee and cocoa have flourished on this fertile land, sustaining farming communities for decades.‚Å£
‚Å£
Peru is a country of abundance, but threats are abundant, too. Peru's 2019 dry season brought an alarming increase in forest fires, which often start with farmers trying to clear land for crops. In Peru, agriculture is a major cause of deforestation (alongside gold mining), with smallholder farmers struggling to make a living on existing cropland clearing nearby forest to expand their growing area.‚Å£
‚Å£
Time and time again, we see how critical farmer livelihoods are for environmental stability. Peru's farmers and Indigenous communities are a powerful example of that.‚Å£
‚Å£
Read about Rainforest Alliance's long-standing partnership with the communities of Peru via the link in our bio.‚Å£
‚Å£
#RainforestAlliance  #ActForAmazonia #Peru üì∏: David Dudenhoefer

Forests are at the HEART of our work. Like and share this post, if forests mean the world to you too üíö Together, we can help keep forests standing ‚Äì‚Äì contributing to a brighter, greener future for generations to come‚Å£. üå¥üå¥‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£And a big thanks to everyone who's been sharing their forest love-stories with us! We'll keep sharing them in our stories all day. ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£#RainforestAlliance #SaveTheTrees #LoveForests #ForestTherapy #NaturalClimateSolutions #ValentinesDay #FollowTheFrog‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£

In the spirit of love, will you share your devotion to forests with us? What deep connections do you have with a forest near you? What are some of your favorite forest memories ‚Äì in near and faraway places? Let us know in the comments below! ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Wanna spread your love even further? Tag us in your best forest-memory photos, and we'll share them in our stories all day!‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£#RainforestAlliance #LoveForests #ForestTherapy #NaturalClimateSolutions #ValentinesDay #FollowTheFrog

Promoting and protecting the human rights of those who produce our food requires bold leadership and a strong alliance to make our food supply more sustainable and equitable. It is a responsibility that MUST be shared by governments, companies, traders, farmers, and forest communities ‚Äî with organizations like the Rainforest Alliance playing an important role in bringing everyone to the table to work for a common vision. ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Most human rights abuses in agricultural and forestry supply chains are rooted in the social, political, and economic challenges of a particular region or country. Our approach to sustainability transformation includes a combination of tools: certification, training programs, sustainable economic development, and advocacy that targets companies and governments.‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Interested in the human rights of farmers & forest communities? Visit the link in our bio to learn more.‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£#RainforestAlliance #HumanRights #JoinOurAlliance üì∏: @sydellewillowsmith

Recent legislative efforts in Brazil to allow commercial mining on Indigenous land ‚Äì‚Äì a move that could mortally threaten Indigenous Amazon communities and accelerate ecosystem collapse ‚Äì‚Äì underscore the urgency of Indigenous land rights.‚Å£
‚Å£ ‚Å£
‚Å£Since our founding in 1987, upholding land rights for Indigenous people ‚Äì‚Äì the world's best forest guardians ‚Äì‚Äì has been core to our work. Although we are encouraged by recent moves of some governments to return land rights to forest communities, we must do much more to advance the rights of Indigenous people around the world. ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Not only is Indigenous territorial sovereignty a human right, it is essential to our shared climate future. Indigenous people manage 35% of the world's standing forests and 80% of our planet's terrestrial biodiversity. Research has demonstrated that their traditional ecological knowledge and land use practices are highly effective in maintaining the balance between people and nature. ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£The Rainforest Alliance works with Indigenous leaders and community partners throughout Latin America, West Africa, and Southeast Asia. We‚Äôve witnessed ‚Äì‚Äì and learned from ‚Äì‚Äì their powerful traditional land stewardship practices in action. We‚Äôve also seen firsthand how violence and land seizures devastate communities and threaten the delicate balance they‚Äôve worked so hard to maintain. ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£With the future of entire ecosystems at stake, it is critically important that we protect the rights of Indigenous peoples to live in and protect their forest homes. ‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Read more about our work to advance the human rights of Indigenous people and more in the link in our bio.‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£#RainforestAlliance #HumanRights #IndigenousRising #IndigenousRights #ClimateJustice #NaturalClimateSolutions #ForestGuardians‚Å£
‚Å£

Happy 30th Anniversary to Guatemala‚Äôs Maya Biosphere Reserve! ‚Å£
‚Å£
This incredible expanse of rainforest (2.1 million hectares), the largest protected area in Central America, is home to iconic wildlife, archeological wonders like Tikal, and many local communities. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Our longtime, cherished partners in the nine community forest concessions of the reserve deserve special congratulations: For more than 17 years, these communities have maintained a near-zero deforestation rate in their areas (20 times less than other parts of the reserve) while maintaining abundant jaguar populations. ‚Å£
‚Å£
They‚Äôve created thriving local economies with forestry practices based on sustainable principles ‚Äî for example, they only harvest 1.4 trees per hectare every 40 years (!), and collect plants and nuts from the forest floor to process and sell (low to no-impact ‚Äî with women most often running the businesses). Needless to say, almost no one migrates out of these communities because people can make a living ‚Äî while in other parts of Guatemala, people are migrating out at a high rate due to economic desperation. So, thank you @acofop for all your hard work to protect the concessions areas and congratulations to Guatemala‚Äôs National Council of Protected Areas (@conap_gt)! We salute you all!‚Å£
‚Å£
#RainforestAlliance #MayaBiosphereReserve #Guatemala #HappyAnniversary #SomosBosquesParaSiempre #SalvemosPeten #30a√±osRBM

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) and Upper Amazon Conservancy (@chrisfagan_uac) for @rainforestalliance: Waiting on one of the occasional planes connecting Puerto Esperanza to the outside world. Thank you for looking at this takeover. And thank you to Rainforest Alliance for allowing me the platform to share our work!

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: Jorge, chief of a Chitonahua community in initial contact on the upper Yur√∫a, Peru applies traditional achiote die to his face. The Chitonahua were forcibly contacted in the mid 1990‚Äôs by mahogany loggers who grew tired of the Chitonahua raiding their camps. Jorge lost his eye to a shotgun blast during one such raid. The Peruvian government considers the Chitonahua and a handful of other tribes as being in initial contact with the outside world. Their lives are a mix traditional customs and beliefs with modern ones like selling crops for money needed to purchase western clothing and other manufactured items. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: Evening traffic in front of some small shops in Puerto Esperanza, Peru. The larger of the remote towns like Puerto Esperanza are the weak bridge between the even more remote indigenous villages and the rest of the world. They have mediocre healthcare, remedial education, infrequently replenished and limited provisions, few economic opportunities, and usually at least several western religious denominations vying for their souls. Some connect to the outside world by incomplete roads, others by rivers so long and so winding that travel on them is measured in days or even months, and distances determined by 'turns' instead of kilometers. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: Workers loading lumber on a truck at the port in Pucallpa, on the Ucayali River in Peru. Pucallpa is well known as one of the centers for trafficking illegal lumber out of the Upper Amazon and a week before this photograph the local paper reported that 4 million board feet of illegal lumber was confiscated at 8 Pucallpa sawmills. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: (1) Marcelino Pinedo Cecilio's community was first contacted in the 1950s by an anthropologist when he was a child. Soon after, many in his community developed sore throats and fevers, and Marcelino says many died from what would have been common western diseases as a result of this contact.
.
(2) Jovita Rengifo Cobos from Imaculada on the Inuya River in Peru tells how her parents grew up enslaved in the rubber and agriculture booms of the early and mid 1900's that spread across the amazon and were forced to work growing barbasco‚Äîthe common name of several plants that contain poisonous chemical compounds used for fishing by indigenous populations and that became important to the pharmaceuticals industry. .
From gold and the earliest Spanish and Portuguese explorers; to rubber and animal skins in the early 1900s; to oil and gas, timber, cattle, and cocaine today, access to and the extraction of natural resources at the expense of the indigenous populations and the ecosystems they rely on has defined life in the Amazon. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: (1) Carlitos (name unverified and likely false) and his family are new arrivals from the coca-growing highlands to the to the lowland jungle and are moving in on land they have freshly cleared for agriculture on the upper Sepahua River, Peru. These plots, increasing in numbers almost daily, are illegal, unknown and unrecognized by officials, and mostly for small farms that appear to be fronts for growing coca deeper in the forests.
.
(2) Aerial drone photograph of deforestation for agriculture near Santa Isabelle de Sepahua, Sepahua River, Peru. In the past year, new deforestation has been showing up in satellite imagery along remote tributaries in the Urubamba watershed in southeastern Peru.
.
(3) Coca leaves for sale at the port in Atalaya, Peru. Coca is a familiar traditional medicine chewed to relieve hunger and fatigue and to enhance physical performance, as well as for stimulating stomach function, treating asthma, colds, and other ailments. The leaves are found for sale in many small shops and markets in Peru from the Andes down into the upper Amazon basin. Cultivation for cocaine production is not traditional here, and drives a powerful and environmentally destructive (i.e., clearing remote forests for crops) illegal industry.
.
(4) A family from the valley of the three rivers Apurimac, Ene and Mantaro (aka, VRAEM or VRAE)‚Äîone of the main areas for cultivation of coca in Peru‚Äîarriving to establish a new settlement on the Sepahua River. Families such as this one are driven out of VRAEM as authorities crack down on illegal drug production and are moving into the remote lowland jungles, often staking claim to plots of land through illegal land grab schemes.
.
I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: A young girl in Nuevo Eden, Peru. This remote Ash√©ninka village far up the Yur√∫a River lives a mostly traditional subsistence lifestyle and shares their territory and the forest with still isolated tribes. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: Drone photograph showing the extent of the deforestation and environmental impact from illegal and unregulated alluvial gold mining in the tropical forests of the Madre de Dios region in Southeastern Peru. The La Pampa ‚Äòscar‚Äô covers approximately 40,000 hectares where miners cleared forests and tapped local rivers and wetlands to liquify and sort soil to extract gold, transforming some of the most biodiverse forests in the world to sand. The illicit industry also drives a host of humanitarian crises including slavery, sex trafficking, health related environmental justice, and indigenous rights violations. In February 2019, Peru assigned 1500 police and military personnel to the La Pampa region in a historic crackdown on gold mining in this region. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @cinciamdd helped with funding and access to the mining area. @ilcp_photographers provided a grant through the Redsecker Response Fund. @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: Linder Miques Viquia, Sepahua Community Vigilance Committee Member patrolling the upper Sepahua River, Peru where illegal land grab schemes are leading to rapid deforestation threatening the indigenous communities and unparalleled biodiversity of multiple critical protected areas. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) for @rainforestalliance: The Chitonahua were forcibly contacted in the mid 1990‚Äôs by mahogany loggers who grew tired of the Chitonahua raiding their camps. The Peruvian government considers the Chitonahua and a handful of other tribes as being in initial contact with the outside world. Their lives are a mix traditional customs and beliefs with modern ones like selling crops for money needed to purchase western clothing and other manufactured items. I've been woking since 2015 with @chrisfagan_uac on Indigenous rights and protected areas. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

I‚Äôm Jason Houston (@jasonbhouston) and I‚Äôll be taking over @rainforestalliance this week with images from my work with @chrisfagan_uac in the Peruvian Amazon. The Pur√∫s/Manu region in¬†southeastern Peru is one of the most remote, inaccessible, and important areas of the¬†Amazon, where still-intact ecosystems provide sustenance for settled indigenous communities and home to one of the highest concentrations of isolated ‚Äúuncontacted‚Äù tribes on Earth. While still largely undeveloped, this¬†last wildest place is increasingly threatened by many deforestation drivers¬†including logging, mining, oil and gas development, cattle grazing, coca cultivation and trafficking, agricultural expansion, and both legal and illegal road construction projects that open up previously inaccessible forests with devastating and irrevocable impacts on the ecosystems and all who depend on them. @ilcp_photographers @lastwildestplace #amazon #deforestation #peru #indigenous #indigenousrights #environment #environmental #conservation #conservationphotography #photojournalism #photojournalist #onassignment #takeover

‚ùóÔ∏èNow more than ever before, it is clear that we must build a global movement for #climatepositivity ‚Äì‚Äì ecological regeneration based on a foundation of environmental justice (h/t @sustainablebk @theslowfactory) ‚Äì‚Äì one that includes businesses, consumers, and the rural people who grow and produce the things we use every day. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Today, our very own Jungwon Kim will take part in CLIMATE POSITIVITY AT SCALE, part of @theslowfactory Study Hall 2020 series at @nytimes Center in NYC. Marine biologist @ayanaeliza, #StudyHall founder @celinecelines, and Kim will explore themes of climate resilience, spiritual ecology, and science in the prologue conversation. The event will also be live-streamed (see @theslowfactory for details). ‚Å£
‚Å£
üå± In the face of our climate emergency, achieving climate-positive transformation at scale is an urgent imperative. As Kim says, "History has shown that when individuals unite for a common cause, their collective actions can become a powerful force for change." The Rainforest Alliance unites communities and businesses at the intersection of agriculture and deforestation to transform destructive supply chains into more sustainable, climate-positive systems. No one organization, community, company, or government can do this alone; this is the moment for everyone to go all-out for climate positivity! ‚Å£
‚Å£
üëâ Follow @theslowfactory for more info, and stay tuned today as we'll be live from the event in our Stories! ‚Å£
‚Å£
#RainforestAlliance #SDGStudyHall #ClimateActionNow #ClimateSummit #Sustainability #Resilience #MarineLife #FollowTheFrog‚Å£
‚Å£

Future forest guardians! üí™üå≥ We're proud to announce that Andrea and Juana Mar√≠a have earned full scholarships to @u_earth in Costa Rica to study Agricultural Sciences!‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
The backstory: A lack of job opportunities in many rural communities like Calakmul in Campeche, Mexico forces young people to seek job opportunities outside their communities. But when these areas lose energetic and innovative youth, they also lose future guardians of their forest.
‚Å£‚Å£
That's why we started the ‚ÄúOur Forest, Our Future‚Äù initiative with the @kelloggfoundation. Last year, 40 young students took part in technical workshops and field experiences focused on the responsible management of the forest they inhabit. In addition, we facilitated further educational alliances and scholarships in environmental studies at pioneering programs focused on sustainability like @u_earth.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚ÄúI feel happy to be able to encourage more girls to study something related to the forest. To prove that being girls, doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt do it.‚Äù - Juana Mar√≠a Mart√≠nez‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚ÄúI want to help my community and the region where I am from. I want to strengthen our productive sector in a sustainable way.‚Äù - Andrea Cort√©s‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
#RainforestAlliance #NuestraSelva #NuestroFuturo #Mexico #Education #Scholarship #EarthUniversity #EnvironmentalScience #FollowTheFrog‚Å£

üíß As the planet continues to warm, droughts create tinderbox conditions in drier climates, from California to Australia, and water shortages are becoming a more-devastating threat every day. Since agriculture consumes 70% of the world's available freshwater, water conservation is a critical component of #ClimateSmartAgriculture. ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£For smallholder farmers, whose livelihoods are dependent on reliable crop yields, learning to adapt and prepare for unpredictable water cycles is even more critical. Planting cover crops to improve soil water retention is just one example of a climate-smart farming technique that can help farmers get ahead.‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Want to know more? Read about our work at the forefront of developing and implementing climate solutions that benefit farmers in the link in our bio.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£ ‚Å£#RainforestAlliance #SustainableAgriculture #NaturalClimateSolutions #ClimateActionNow #ClimateResilience #WaterIsLife #FollowTheFrog

Climate change is turning the lives of farmers upside down. ‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£That's why we proudly promote climate-smart agriculture -- a way of combining various sustainable farming methods to tackle the specific climate challenges of a specific community. The first step is to assess the particular climate risks, since a farm facing prolonged water shortages will need different strategies than one confronting frequent flooding, for example. ‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚ÄúWhere drought and prolonged dry seasons are the main risks, a climate-smart approach might focus on planting cover crops or mulching to improve soil structure, water infiltration and retention, and overall soil fertility,‚Äù Rainforest Alliance environment director Martin Noponen explains. ‚ÄúIn places where the risks are heavy rain and flooding, a climate-smart approach would likely focus on trenching, planting cover crops, and controlling surface water runoff with activities like vegetation barriers.‚Äù‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£Finding the right combination to manage a specific farm‚Äôs climate challenges‚Äîand to build resilience to future impacts‚Äîis what makes climate-smart agriculture ‚Äúsmart.‚Äù‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£##RainforestAlliance #SustainableAgriculture #ClimateSmart #NaturalClimateSolutions #ClimateActionNow #ClimateResilience #FollowTheFrog üì∏: @creagh‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£
